content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 may be cited as the Act. It includes higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002, also known as the Act, increases penalties for mail and wire fraud, as well as securities fraud under Section 1348 of title 18, United States Code. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 enhances penalties for fraud related to securities registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 or the Securities Act of 1933, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, including tampering with records or obstructing official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. It also amends the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission is requested to promptly review and consider new sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud. They are also asked to provide enhancements for officers or directors of publicly traded corporations who commit fraud and related offenses, and to submit policy recommendations to Congress for combating these offenses. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, enhance penalties for corporate officers committing fraud, and submit policy recommendations to Congress for combating these offenses. The Commission should ensure guidelines reflect the seriousness of these offenses and consider any circumstances that may justify exceptions. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud, enhance penalties for corporate officers committing fraud, and submit policy recommendations to Congress for combating these offenses. The guidelines should assure consistency, account for aggravating or mitigating circumstances, ensure adequacy of offense levels for obstruction of justice and fraud offenses, and make necessary conforming changes to sentencing. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review and enhance sentencing guidelines for fraud offenses, make necessary changes to ensure consistency and adequacy of penalties, and submit policy recommendations to Congress. The Commission is also urged to act promptly and issue the guidelines or amendments within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include a new paragraph (19) that covers claims for violations of Federal securities laws, State securities laws, or common law fraud in connection with the purchase or sale of any security. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) that addresses claims related to violations of securities laws, fraud, deceit, or manipulation in connection with the purchase or sale of securities. This covers judgments, orders, settlements, fines, penalties, and other payments resulting from legal proceedings or agreements entered into by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section requiring corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The certification must confirm the accuracy of the financial statements in representing the issuer's operations and financial condition. Violations of this requirement may result in criminal penalties. The new section in Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, requires corporate officers to certify the accuracy of financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. Violations of this certification may lead to criminal penalties, including fines and imprisonment. SEC. 7 introduces penalties for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses against the United States, while SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 8 amends the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to increase criminal penalties to $5,000,000 or 20 years imprisonment, and SEC. 9 grants temporary freeze authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to grant the Securities and Exchange Commission temporary freeze authority in cases involving possible violations of federal securities laws by publicly traded companies or their personnel. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 grants the SEC temporary freeze authority in cases of potential violations by publicly traded companies or personnel. If the issuer is likely to make extraordinary payments to certain individuals, the SEC can petition a court for a temporary order to escrow those payments for 45 days. The court must provide notice and a hearing before entering the order, unless impracticable or contrary to the public interest. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the SEC to freeze assets temporarily in cases of potential violations. A temporary order can be issued to escrow payments for 45 days if the issuer is expected to make extraordinary payments. The order becomes effective immediately, must be served to the parties involved, and remains enforceable unless modified by a court within 45 days. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the SEC to issue temporary orders freezing assets for up to 45 days, with a possible extension of another 45 days upon court approval. If violations are charged before the order expires, the issuer or other party involved must face the consequences. If the issuer or other person described in subparagraph (A) is charged with a violation of Federal securities laws before the temporary order expires, the order will remain in effect until legal proceedings are concluded, with the right to petition the court for review. If the issuer or other person described in subparagraph (A) is not charged with any violation of the Federal securities laws before the temporary order expires, the escrow will terminate at the end of the effective period, and disputed payments will be returned with accrued interest. The disputed payments with accrued interest will be returned to the issuer or affected person. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 21C(c)(2) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to give the Commission the authority to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933 are amended to allow the Commission to bar individuals who violate regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Commission may issue an order prohibiting a person from serving as an officer or director if their conduct demonstrates unfitness. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to bar individuals from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers if their conduct shows unfitness. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information on Federal offenses to law enforcement. Penalties include fines or up to 10 years imprisonment.
